content.question:
Half-Reaction 
Standard Reduction Potential <math alttext="in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="A l, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 3 solid plus 3 electrons produce A l solid plus 3 O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Al(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Al</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="negative 2.31 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.31</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="O 2 gas plus 2 H 2 O liquid plus 4 electrons react to produce 4 O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="positive 0.40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 

The table above provides the half-reactions and standard reduction potentials needed to determine if an Al-air fuel cell can be constructed. Which of the following equations best supports the possibility of obtaining electrical energy from such a cell?

choices.label: <math alttext="E naught sub cell equals positive 0.40 minus negative 2.31, volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>[</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.31</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo><mo>]</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction equals the negative of the fraction with numerator 12 times 96500 times 2.71, and denominator 1000, kilojoules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>96</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mn>2.71</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow></mfrac><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E naught sub cell equals positive 0.40 minus negative 2.31, volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>[</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.31</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo><mo>]</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction equals the negative of the fraction with numerator 4 times 96500 times 2.71, and denominator 1000, kilojoules" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mi>G</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mo>×</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mn>96</mn> <mo>,</mo> <mn>500</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mo>×</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mn>2.71</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>,</mo> <mn>000</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ</mtext> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

<math alttext="E naught sub cell equals negative 2.31 minus positive 0.40, volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>[</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2.31</mn><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>]</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction equals the negative of the fraction with numerator 4 times 96500 times 2.71, and denominator 1000, kilojoules" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mi>G</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>12</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mo>×</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mn>96</mn> <mo>,</mo> <mn>500</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mo>×</mo> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"> </mspace> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2.71</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>,</mo> <mn>000</mn> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ</mtext> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
